title: 7 Times It's Actually Worth Using Spatial Audio
description: Spatial audio doesn't always work, but sometimes, it's just what you need for that extra immersion.
author: Jayric Maning
excerpt: Spatial audio doesn't always work, but sometimes, it's just what you need for that extra immersion.
text: Quick Links Virtual Reality Experiences Listening to Tracks Mixed for Spatial Audio Accessibility for the Hearing Impaired Spatial Audio for Video Calls Spatial audio seems an awesome idea for enhancing our auditory experience through simulated three-dimensional space. However, it doesn't always sound like it should. So, where exactly is spatial audio useful? 7 Playing FPS Games DC Studio / Shutterstock First-person shooter (FPS) games demand quick reflexes and sharp situational awareness. The extra stimuli from simulated 3D audio make it easier for players to recognize their in-game surroundings, providing better situational awareness. In competitive FPS titles like Counter-Strike and Valorant, knowing exactly where an enemy is located can mean the difference between winning and losing. Spatial audio allows players to hear footsteps, reloads, or gunfire with precise directionality. Instead of guessing, players can have a good idea of where the sound is coming from. Spatial audio in FPS games makes you a better player and enhances your experience, even in single-player games. For example, having spatial audio while playing Left4Dead makes the environment more alive (or dead), and immerses you to the world the game developers had intended for you to experience. So, whether you're playing a competitive shooter or just looking to better immerse yourself in a game, try wearing headphones. I recommend an open-back headphone as it provides a better sound stage, making the spatial audio sound more natural. 6 Virtual Reality Experiences Virtual reality (VR) thrives on immersion, and spatial audio is a critical piece of that puzzle. While VR headsets provide a visual escape into other worlds, the experience feels incomplete without realistic sound. Your VR experience won't be as immersive or as enjoyable compared to one with spatial audio. VR concerts and virtual tourism have also become a thing. People can now host and attend virtual concerts and meetups. Imagine attending a live virtual concert where you hear the band from the stage's direction while the crowd's cheers surround you. Spatial audio brings these experiences closer to reality, making VR more engaging and life-like. VR training is another application where spatial audio is crucial. VR training programs for pilots, racers, or even firefighters require spatial audio to better simulate the real world and make training more effective. 5 Immersive Movie Nights Nate Williams/MakeUseOf A home theater setup with spatial audio turns a movie night into a cinematic adventure. Technologies like Dolby Atmos create an auditory experience where sound moves around you in a three-dimensional space. Instead of hearing a jet fly by, you feel it zooming overhead. Explosions erupt from all sides, and dialogue sounds more intimate, as if the characters are in the room. Streaming platforms like Netflix, Disney+, and Apple TV+ support spatial audio for compatible movies and shows. Popular blockbusters such as Avengers: Endgame or Dune are mixed in Dolby Atmos to give viewers a more immersive experience. Paired with the right surround sound system, spatial audio recreates the magic of the cinema. For those with limited space or budget, soundbars like the Sonos Arc or headphones like the AirPods Pro can still deliver impressive spatial audio experiences. Experiencing immersive movie nights has never been more affordable. 4 ASMR and Relaxation Spatial audio has found a unique place in ASMR (Autonomous Sensory Meridian Response) content. ASMR videos and recordings aim to relax listeners by triggering tingling sensations with soft sounds like whispering, tapping, or brushing. Spatial audio enhances these effects by placing sounds all around the listener, creating a deeply personal and calming experience. With platforms like YouTube and Spotify, you can now get the full ASMR experience with a multitude of tracks already mixed for spatial audio. Aside from ASMR, spatial audio is also used for meditative practices to simulate serene environments such as a rainforest, a Zen garden, or ocean waves. Some people even use spatial audio to simulate a library while studying or a commercial gym while working at home. It's amazing how you can use spatial audio to increase focus and reduce stress just by using a pair of headphones and some free spatial audio tracks you can find on the internet. 3 Listening to Tracks Mixed for Spatial Audio Music has always been a powerful medium, and spatial audio takes it to a new level. When tracks are mixed specifically for spatial audio, listeners can experience instruments and vocals from different angles and depths. It feels like the band is performing around you rather than in front of you. Streaming platforms like Apple Music, Amazon Music HD, and Tidal offer a growing library of songs mixed in Dolby Atmos or Sony 360 Reality Audio. Popular artists like Billie Eilish, The Weeknd, and Hans Zimmer have embraced spatial audio to bring their music to life in ways that stereo simply cannot. This format is not just a gimmick; it's a creative tool for artists. It provides a richer, more dynamic listening experience, making it a worthwhile upgrade for music enthusiasts. 2 Accessibility for the Hearing Impaired Spatial audio also has significant applications for individuals with hearing impairments. Enhancing sound localization helps users distinguish between multiple audio sources in environments like classrooms, offices, or crowded spaces. This improved clarity makes auditory information more accessible. Assistive listening devices incorporating spatial audio provide a natural way to identify where sounds originate. For example, hearing aids or cochlear implants with spatial audio can help users navigate social interactions, meetings, or even outdoor environments more effectively. Virtual meetings also benefit from spatial audio accessibility features. Hearing-impaired individuals often struggle with overlapping voices in online calls. Spatial audio separates speakers into different "locations," making it easier to follow conversations and identify who is speaking. 1 Spatial Audio for Video Calls The rise of remote work and virtual communication has made video calls a daily reality for many. Spatial audio enhances video calls by creating a more natural conversational experience. Instead of all voices sounding like they're coming from the same spot, spatial audio places each participant's voice in a unique location. This mimics in-person interactions where sound directionality helps distinguish speakers. Platforms like Zoom and Microsoft Teams have begun exploring spatial audio integrations. These tools can reduce cognitive load by making conversations easier to follow, especially during large meetings. For example, if one speaker is "on the left" and another "on the right," it's simpler to identify who's talking without constant visual cues. Spatial audio also improves engagement in virtual events, such as webinars or online classes. Simulating realistic sound environments keeps participants focused and reduces fatigue. Spatial audio is more than just a technical marvel—it's a transformative tool that enhances how we experience sound in everyday life. Incorporating spatial audio into these activities elevates the overall experience, making interactions more immersive and enjoyable.
